titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Paul Ehrlich and Martha Marquardt papers (Wellcome collection) FA136
titlestmt.author: Beate I. Hirsch

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-10-29 00:25:34 -0400.

did.unittitle: Paul Ehrlich and Martha Marquardt papers (Wellcome collection)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Paul Ehrlich, 1854-1915, physician and scientist, Berlin and Frankfurt, Germany. Founder of hematology, pioneer and major contributor to the fields of histochemistry and immunology. Famous for his development of chemotherapy (arsphenamine - 606) for syphilis. Nobel Laureate in physiology or medicine in 1908, jointly with Elie Metchnikoff for their studies in immunology.

Martha Marquardt, 1873-1956, secretary to Paul Ehrlich from 1902-1915. Author of two books about Paul Ehrlich, "Paul Ehrlich" als Mensch und Arbeiter", 1924. "Paul Ehrlich" in English 1949 and in German 1950. Moving force behind the publication of "The Collected Papers of Paul Ehrlich", 1956 and transcriber of 47 volumes of Paul Ehrlich's copy-books. Author of various plays and articles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This special collection of the Rockefeller University pertains to two individual. The material was sorted accordingly into two distinct collections, entitled "Paul Ehrlich Material" and "Martha Marquardt Material".

The collection consists of letters received by Paul Ehrlich, a synopsis of their contents, handwritten manuscripts by Paul Ehrlich, contracts between Ehrlich-Behring and Hoechst. Handwritten notes and "blocks" by Ehrlich. Reprints, photographs, paper cuttings and obituary notices. The collection contains some Paul Ehrlich memorabilia and an oil painting.

The Martha Marquardt part of the collection contains voluminous correspondence, letters received by Martha Marquardt as well as carbon copies of letters written by her. It contains material regarding her two books about Paul Ehrlich, many articles and plays she wrote, as well as a film she made about flies. There are many photographs of Martha Marquardt, her family and friends. There are some reprints and books and because of her long-standing friendship with Sir Almroth Wright, there are some items concerning him.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: The material in the combined collection was in Martha Marquardt's possession at the time of her death in 1956. Many of the items in the "Paul Ehrlich Material" were sent to her after World War II, when she had emigrated to England. These items had been stored in Geneva, where Mrs. Hedwig Ehrlich had fled to in 1939. A list of articles from the "Geneva Chest" is part of this collection (Box 2a, Folder 1). Many of these items on this list have been deposited at The Rockefeller University Archives by the 2 grandsons of Paul Ehrlich, Hans and Günther Schwerin, in 1978.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers and memorabilia of Paul Ehrlich and Martha Marquardt were deposited, with The Rockefeller University Archives in May 1980 by the Trustees of the will of Sir Henry Solomon Wellcome.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note

eventgrp.event: Born March 14 in Strehlen, Silesia, of Jewish parents
Graduated from Maria Magdalena Gymnasium in Breslau
M. D. from the University of Leipzig, after studies at the Universities of Breslau, Strassburg and Freiburg
Assistant physician at the Charité Hospital in Berlin, (later senior physician)
Received the Professor title from the state
Married Hedwig Pinkus
Birth of daughter Stefanie
Birth of daughter Marianne
Became Privat Docent (Lecturer); Resigned from post at the Charité Hospital
Without formal position. Because of contracted tuberculosis cured in Italy and Egypt for some months
Return to Berlin, establishing a private research laboratory
Became Ausserordentlicher Professor at the University of Berlin

Received a post holding clinical responsibilities at the Moabit Hospital in Berlin.; Was offered laboratory space by Robert Koch in the new Institute for Infectious Diseases where most of the immunology work was done
Was made Director of the State Institute for Serum Research and Serum Control in Steglitz. Became Geheimer Medicinal Rath
Move of the Institute to Frankfurt, renamed to Institute for Experimental Therapy
Addition of the Georg Speyer-Haus to the Institute for continued research on chemotherapy
Became Geheimer Obermedicinal Rath
Received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, sharing it with Elie Metchnikoff for their contributions to immunology
First report on Salvarsan treatment for syphilis
Became Wirklicher Geheimrath with the title of Excellency
Was made Ordentlicher Professor at the newly established University of Frankfurt
Died August 20
University of Chicago, LL.D.
University of Oxford, D.C.L.
University of Athens, Dr. phil. h.c.
University of Breslau, Dr. med. h.c.
Tiedemann Prize
The Prussian Golden Medal of Science
Prize of Honor at the XVth International Congress of Medicine at Lisbon
Nobel Prize
Leibig Medal
Cameron Prize of the University of Edinburgh

bioghist.p: Paul Ehrlich was made honorary, corresponding or foreign member to some 83 international scientific societies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typed by Martha Marquardt listing 7 letters regarding authors' opinions about Behring.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Letters are now filed in alphabetical order.

did.unittitle: Minister of Education and Medical Affairs, Ehrlich to minister

did.physdesc: 16 letters, handwritten and typescript with signature
2 letters, typescript with signature; printed minutes of a session in parliament

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: typescript copy of Ehrlich letter (original with Himmelweit - Note by Martha Marquardt)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Martha Marquardt made a synopsis of the letters after they were sent to the Wellcome Museum in London. The letters had been taken by Hedwig Ehrlich to Geneva and stored there until their transferal was requested by Mr. Günther Schwerin. This is indicated by a cover sheet which reads: Contents of letters to Ehrlich in the chest which was sent from Geneva to the Wellcome Museum, London, by request to Mr. Günther Schwerin, New York. There is a bound copy of this synopsis, 3 typescript copies. A photocopy was made to check the letters received against this synopsis. Some letters listed in the synopsis are missing; others were removed and placed in more appropriate places within this collection.
Typed list of contents from the Geneva chest, 6 pages.

did.unittitle: Contract between Hoechst and Ehrlich re: production of Diphtheria antitoxin, dated March 22, 1894, sig. by Laubenheimer. Handwritten promise by Ehrlich to give Behring 2/3 of proceeds after 1897, dated April 15, 1894
Handwritten contract by Ehrlich, explaining which experimental animals belong to Ehrlich and which to Behring

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: essay in which Behring puts forth his reasons why there should be a central state institute for research to develop therapeutic agents for infectious diseases. Addressed to Althoff who sent it to Ehrlich with comments on margin, 13 pages, dated May 6, 1906. Typescript copy by Martha Marquardt.

did.unittitle: Papers dealing with Behring's request to have his "Tulase" tested by Ehrlich

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: handwritten copy (Abschrift) of Behring's request to Althoff that Ehrlich test his "Tulase", also a copy of Althoff s request to review the matter, presumably to Ehrlich, also typescript copy of Behring's request. Typescript letter by Eilsberger to Ehrlich, dated Dec. 18, 1906 re: Ehrlich's testing of Behring's Tulase-Lactin. Also typescript copy.

did.unittitle: Announcement letters of honorary memberships to societies; honorary doctor, and Nobel Prize

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Typescript letter announcing that Ehrlich was elected a member of the Imperial Health Council, dated July 4, 1910, issued by the Imperial Chancellor; another letter dated July 14, 1910 announcing the same appointment, issued by the Minister of Educational and Medical Affairs, Steinmetz signed.

did.unittitle: Letter announcing honorary membership of Paul Ehrlich to the Therapeutic Society of the University of Moscow, dated April 25, 190?. Letter announcing foreign membership of Paul Ehrlich in the Royal Scientific Society of Göttingen, dated Oct. 14, 1904. Pamphlet in Latin announcing honorary doctor for Paul Ehrlich 1907 (Oxford U?)
Letter announcing the Nobel Prize for Paul Ehrlich, dated Oct. 29, 1908
Letter announcing honorary membership to the German Tropical Medical Society
Paul Ehrlich. "Über den jetztigen Stand der Lehre von eosinophilen Zellen"
Paul Ehrlich. "Über die Diazo Reaction im Harn"

eventgrp.event: Born December 7 in Labes, Pommerania, of Lutheran parents
Grammar and Middle schooling in Labes
Emigration to America, stay with family members
Household work, later learning secretarial skills and holding of several secretarial positions in New York
Return to Germany and continued employment as bilingual secretary in Worms
Secretary to Paul Ehrlich in Frankfurt
Continued employment at the Institute for Experimental Research after Paul Ehrlich's death in 1915
Dismissal from the Institute
Publication of book: "Paul Ehrlich als Mensch und Arbeiter"
Various secretarial positions in Frankfurt
Move to Berlin to learn laboratory techniques and microcinematography. Making of an educational film on flies
Move to Paris to learn French

Voluntary exile in Paris. Support by means of translations, tutoring and various secretarial jobs. Publications of articles in newspapers, as well as the publication of the book: "Die Kleinen Leute von Paris". Expansion of manuscript of first book on Paul Ehrlich. Copyrights of "Paul Ehrlich als Mensch und Arbeiter" sold to Warner Bros. for the film: "Dr. Ehrlich's Magic Bullet".
Marginal existence in Paris during war years and German occupation
Emigration to England with the help of Sir Almroth Wright and Sir Alexander Fleming
Translation of expanded manuscript and publication of German and English versions of book called: Paul Ehrlich

Moving force behind the publication of "The Collected Papers of Paul Ehrlich", edited by F. Himmelweit, with a foreword by Sir Henry Dale. Partial transcription of 47 volumes of the Paul Ehrlich copy books.
Participation of the Paul Ehrlich Centennial celebration in Frankfurt
Died July 14

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Martha Marquardt private correspondence: because of the personal nature of the letters in Box No. 6 and Box No. 7, this correspondence was not incorporated in the remaining correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He was found with his throat slashed in Milwaukee in November 1913. This folder contains correspondence from his landlady, Louis Scheit, as well as various letters, papers and documents returned by Louis Scheit to Martha Marquardt.

3 telegrams regarding illness and death of parents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This correspondence with Hans, a son of Lore Hinsen, covers the war years 1914-1918. He was killed in 1918. There are 71 letters, as well as about 50 photographs.

did.unittitle: Hans Hinsen. 1 letter by Lore Hinsen dated Dec. 22, 1918

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Martha Marquardt's correspondence about Martha Geissler. The 2 Marthas lived together for many years and in a letter to Miss Münch, Martha Marquardt explains why they separated, dated Oct. 23, 1919.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains English, French and German articles written by Martha Marquardt on the occasion of Ehrlich's 80th and 85th birthdays. She sent these articles to various publishing houses and in addition to the typescript copies of these articles, there is correspondence with the publishing houses, as well as some paper clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 13 typewritten pages of Martha Marquardt's account of her trip to Frankfurt in search of any surviving Paul Ehrlich material, mainly reprints of his scientific publications.

did.unittitle: 2 science radio programs produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation in 1936
Material dealing with the book: Paul Ehrlich

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Martha Marquardt's enlarged version of her book on Paul Ehrlich. After her book "Paul Ehrlich als Mensch und Arbeiter" was published in 1924, she worked on a more detailed account of Paul Ehrlich's life. The German manuscript was finished during the war years in Paris. When she arrived in London she translated this German version into English. The English book was published in 1949 by William Heinemann Medical Books Ltd. The German book was published in 1951 by Springer Verlag. Sir Henry Dale wrote a foreword which appeared in both versions.

did.unittitle: Enlarged version, in English, entitled "Paul Ehrlich" by Martha Marquardt

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: German version, a few pages are missing. 45 printers copies of photographs used in the book.

did.unittitle: German version of Sir Henry Dale's introduction, 14 typewritten pages; Martha Marquardt's introduction in German, 3 typewritten pages

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remarks on Paul Ehrlich and his work by friends and contemporaries - 121 typewritten pages by Martha Marquardt. "Anhang" - same as above, in German, 14 typewritten pages.

did.unittitle: Notes by Martha Marquardt about the English and German versions of her book
Reviews of Martha Marquardt's book "Paul Ehrlich"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Paper clippings and articles in various journals, including The Lancet, Saturday Review, The Jewish Monthly, British Journal of Venereal Diseases and Therapeutische Umschau..

did.unittitle: Material dealing with "The Collected papers of Paul Ehrlich"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 16 typewritten pages, describing Martha Marquardt's endeavors to have Paul Ehrlich's scientific papers published as a collection. Bibliography: 38 typewritten pages with many corrections covering the years 1877 to 1915. This may be a complete bibliography of Paul Ehrlich.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Many typewritten pages and handwritten notes regarding Paul Ehrlich's bibliography.

did.unittitle: Various lists of addresses, some of personal friends of Martha Marquardt. Some of the lists were compiled to request financial support for a publication of Paul Ehrlich's collected papers, before the Wellcome Trust gave a grant for this publication

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Karl Weigert, a distant relative of Carl Weigert compiled a family tree with the help of other relatives. This folder contains some photocopies of articles about Karl Weigert, correspondence with The Wellcome Foundation), a typewritten family tree, as well as a schematic drawing of the Weigert family tree.

scopecontent.p: Printer's proofs of "The Collected Papers of Paul Ehrlich".

1 photograph album presented to Martha Marquardt of pictures taken during the centennial celebration

did.physdesc: Some of Martha Marquardt's photographic material could not be shipped to New York as was, because of flammability of the old nitrate films and negatives; copies were made

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: RAC is unable to provide access to the original item, due to the specialized equipment necessary to facilitate playback. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply. See RAC Head of Archival Services or RAC Head of Digital Programs for details.

did.physdesc: 4 empty boxes (presumably the original rolls were in these)
21 small plastic bags containing tissue papers and labels, but no negatives

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The extensive correspondence between Martha Marquardt and Wright is in Box 12, Folder 9.
